section.title: Deploying Rex
section.para: This chapter describes how to configure and run Rex.

section.title: First Time Configuration
section.para: Before running Rex for the first time, there are a few steps you need to take. Rex requires access to a database. Currently, Rex supports PostgreSQL and Microsft SQL Server. This database is where RETS data is stored, as well as Rex specific information. Rex requires read/write access to the database, as well as the ability to create new tables.

section.title: PostgreSQL Setup
section.para: PostgreSQL must be configured to accept TCP/IP connections, as this is how the JDBC driver connects. This is done adding the following setting in postgresql.conf:
You may also have to edit pg_hba.conf to make network connections permissible. See the documentation in that file for details.
It is probably a good idea to create a user other than the default postgres superuser. This user must have read and write access, and permissions to create new tables in the database used by Rex.
The JDBC driver for Postgres version 7.4.x is included with the distribution.

section.title: Installing a JDBC Driver
section.para: The easiest way to install your JDBC driver is to use the Administration Tool. Choose the Install Jar command from the File menu. You must then restart the Administration Tool and/or Rex to use the new JDBC driver.

section.title: Configuring Database Properties
section.para: From the Configuration tab of the Administration Tool, the current database properties are listed. You will have change these to suit your environment. Click on the Edit button, to bring up the Database Properties dialog, as in . You should use the Test Connection button to make sure that the properties are entered correctly. If the test fails, then neither the Administration Tool nor Rex will be able to access your database.

section.title: Creating the Schema
section.para: Rex needs tables for it's own use, such as user information. Before you create users and groups, you need to create these tables by chosing the Create Schema command from the Database menu.

section.title: Configuring RETS Parameters
section.para: From the main Configuration panel, as seen in , you can configure various RETS parameters.

The Listening Port is the TCP port number that the Rex server listens on. 6103 is the standard, well-known port number for RETS. The Metadata Directory points to the root directory of the metadata hierarchy. Configuring metadata is explained in . The Image Root and Image Pattern parameters are used to allow Rex to serve up images for the GetObject transaction. The Image Root is a directory where the images are located. The Image Pattern is a percent substitution pattern that describes the format of the actual file names. The possible patterns and their substitutions are listed in .

row.entry: Object Index, or empty if index is 0

section.para:
For example, if you have pictures in /home/rex/pictures/. The key is used as the base file name, with each image given a number. Say there are three pictures for the property ID LN1001, the full paths for these pictures are:
/home/rex/pictures/LN1001_1.jpg
/home/rex/pictures/LN1001_2.jpg
/home/rex/pictures/LN1001_3.jpg
The, you could set the Image Root to /home/rex/pictures and the Image Pattern to %k_%i.jpg. The %k gets replaced with the object ID, and the %i gets replaced with the image number.

The %k percent pattern may be proceeded by a number modifier that truncates the number of characters used during substitution. This allows files to be split up into multiple directories for large installations. If the number is positive, the characters are taken from the front, where if the number is negative, the characters are taken from the end. So, with a pattern of %-2k/%k_%i.jpg, the first picture for LN1001, LN1002, LN1101 would be at the following paths:
/home/rex/pictures/01/LN1001_1.jpg
/home/rex/pictures/02/LN1002_1.jpg
/home/rex/pictures/01/LN1101_1.jpg

section.title: Users
section.para: Users are managed through the Users Tab as seen in . Users may be created, removed, and edited from the User menu or contextual menu. Users may also be added and removed from groups.

section.title: Groups
section.para: Groups are manged through the Groups Tab as seen in . Groups may be created and removed from the Group menu or contextual menu.

Group rules allow access to fields to be restricted for members of this group. Rules are written for a particular resource and class. There two types of rules: include and exlude. Include rules includes on the fields listed. Exclude rules includes all fields except the ones listed. An example rule is shown in . The individual fields are listed with spaces between them. If a user is a member of multiple groups, then the fields allowed to be seen are a union of the fields of each group's set of fields.

section.title: Configuring Metadata
section.para: Metadata describes how to map property data in your relational database to RETS names. The metadata is stored as compact format metadata, split into multiple files. For more information on compact metadata format, see RETS specification. A sample set of metadata is provided on the Rex website, and should be used as a starting point.
